text: Perhaps the most striking distinction of archaea is the complete absence of archaeal pathogens of animals or plants.
Their size is limited by diffusion across the cell membrane, with occasional exceptions, such as the “giant bacterium” Epulopiscium fishelsoni.
All cells consist of membrane-enclosed compartments that shelter the same fundamental apparatus of cell production: the DNA-RNAprotein machine.
And genomes reveal evidence of gene transfer between bacteria and archaea sharing high-temperature habitats.
The pair of paralogs chosen for analysis must have diverged within the common ancestral cell before the divergence of the three domains of life.
Only the domain Archaea includes species capable of growth in the most many other archaeal species grow well at mesophilic temperatures in soil or water.

The two domains share closely related components of the central DNA-RNA-protein machine: Even such hallmarks of eukaryotes as intragenic introns, why rRNA trees place archaea closer to eukaryotes than to Nevertheless, eukaryotes share fundamental structures with bacteria that differ from those in archaea.
While the position of the root remains controversial, the three major divisions of life based on rRNA phylogeny have been confirmed by sequence data from the numerous genomes published to date.
Yet the tree also shows signs of gene flow unaccounted for by monophyletic descent.
By contrast, the prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea) employ a wider range of metabolic alternatives, including lithotrophy and anaerobic respiration.
Outside the archaea, ether-linked membrane lipids are found only in deepbranching bacterial species that share habitat (and exchange genes) with hyperthermophilic archaea.

The early divergence is determined by comparing the pair’s sequence similarity in many different organisms and constructing a tree genes with different functions have been subjected to natural selection in addition to random variation.
The eukaryotes contain mitochondria derived from assimilated bacteria whose genomes persist within the organelle.

The larger size and complexity of eukaryotic cells mean that they generally require the most highly powered sources of energy, such as aerobic respiration and oxygenic photosynthesis, although some protists conduct fermentation.
Overall, the three-domain phylogeny divides life usefully into three distinctive groups.
Even the many methanogens that live within animal digestive tracts have never been shown to cause disease.
On the other hand, eukaryotes share key traits with archaea that distinguish both from bacteria.
Bacteria and archaea possess no nucleus and have relatively simple intracellular membranes.
Eukaryotic organelles include mitochondria and chloroplasts, which evolved from internalized bacteria.
The root, however, can be found only by measuring divergence relative to an outside group of organisms.

Most phylogenetic data so far indicate a root between Bacteria and the common ancestor of Archaea and Eukarya; that is, Bacteria diverged from Archaea and Eukarya before Archaea and Eukarya diverged from each other.
Nonetheless, important differences emerge between each pair of domains; indeed, each domain shows distinctive traits absent or scarce in the other two.
Of the three domains, the eukaryotes stand out as having a nucleus and other complex membranous organelles (see Table 17.2).
The fundamental components of this machine appear to have evolved before the three domains diverged from their last universal common ancestor.
Furthermore, structural and physiological comparison of the three domains largely confirms the rRNA tree (Table 17.2).
Archaea possess unique cell membrane components, such as their ether-linked lipids (see Chapter 19).
Finally, eukaryotic plants and animals have attained a degree of multicellular complexity unknown in the prokaryotic domains.
What if the tree of life is not strictly monophyletic?
The core information machinery of eukaryotes more closely resembles that of archaea.
Archaea, bacteria, and eukaryotes.

We summarize here the major features common to most members of each domain.
From a molecular standpoint, all cells on Earth appear more similar than they are different.
Note first that all living cells on Earth share profound similarities.

Since no “outgroup” exists for the tree of all life, how is the tree rooted?
archaea argue that archaea represent a model system for related processes in complex eukaryotes such as humans.
